section.name: Configure a Hadoop cluster for a debian or ubuntu node
section.p: For this tutorial, we use Cloudera Distribution for Hadoop (CDH) for the cluster installation on an Debian/Ubuntu system. For more information about this distribution see the Cloudera distribution documentation.

subsection.name: Package installation
subsection.p: You need to install the packages on all the nodes of your cluster. In /etc/apt/sources.list add the following line (replace maverick by the name of the version of your system, e.g. karmic, lucid, lenny...):
Add the public key for Cloudera packages:
subsection.source: $ sudo apt-get install hadoop-0.20 hadoop-0.20-conf-pseudo hadoop-0.20-doc hadoop-0.20-source

subsection.name: Configuration files
subsection.p: Create a directory for cluster configuration:

CDH uses alternatives to manage your Hadoop configuration so that you can easily switch between cluster configurations. Change the alternative for hadoop configuration to the my_cluster configuration:
Now we can edit the configuration files in /etc/hadoop-0.20/conf.my_cluster. We provide here samples of configurations files for a small cluster.

ul.li: The core-site.xml configuration file contains the name of the master node and the path to hadoop data on the node. Here, a sample of a core-site.xml:
ul.source:
<?xml version="1.0"?> <?xml-stylesheet type="text/xsl" href="configuration.xsl"?>
<configuration> <property> <name>fs.default.name</name> <value>hdfs://master.example.com:8020</value> <description> The name of the default file system. A URI whose scheme and authority determine the FileSystem implementation. The uri's scheme determines the config property (fs.SCHEME.impl) naming the FileSystem implementation class. The uri's authority is used to determine the host, port, etc. for a filesystem. </description> </property>
<property> <name>hadoop.tmp.dir</name> <value>/var/lib/hadoop-0.20/cache/${user.name}</value> <description>A base for other temporary directories.</description> </property> </configuration>
ul.li: The hdfs-site.xml file contains the configuration of the distributed file system:
ul.source:
<?xml version="1.0"?> <?xml-stylesheet type="text/xsl" href="configuration.xsl"?>
<configuration> <property> <name>dfs.replication</name> <value>3</value> <description> Default block replication. The actual number of replications can be specified when the file is created. The default is used if replication is not specified in create time. </description> </property> <property> <name>dfs.permissions</name> <value>false</value> </property> <!--property--> <!-- specify this so that running 'hadoop namenode -format' formats the right dir --> <!--name>dfs.name.dir</name> <value>/var/lib/hadoop-0.20/cache/hadoop/dfs/name</value> </property--> </configuration>
ul.li: The mapred-site.xml file contains the configuration of map-reduce:
ul.source:
<?xml version="1.0"?> <?xml-stylesheet type="text/xsl" href="configuration.xsl"?>
<configuration> <property> <name>mapred.job.tracker</name> <value>master.example.com:8021</value> <description> The host and port that the MapReduce job tracker runs at. If "local", then jobs are run in-process as a single map and reduce task. </description> </property> </configuration>
ul.li: In hadoop-end.sh set the path to java. We strongly recommand to use Sun JRE. You can also disable IPv6 support of hadoop.
ul.source: export JAVA_HOME=/usr/lib/jvm/java-6-sun # Disable IPv6 for hadoop export HADOOP_OPTS=-Djava.net.preferIPv4Stack=true

subsection.p: Once the configuration of the master node is ready, copy the content of the configuration directory on configuration directory of all the other nodes of your cluster.

subsection.name: Starting Hadoop
subsection.p: Before starting Hadoop for the fisrt time, you need to format the distributed file system of each node:
Start the services for all the nodes:
subsection.source: $ sudo service hadoop-0.20-datanode start && \ sudo service hadoop-0.20-tasktracker start
subsection.p: Start dedicated services to the master node:
subsection.source: $ sudo service hadoop-0.20-namenode start && \ sudo service hadoop-0.20-jobtracker start
